instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no fan
threads.message: Hi again i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no fan  i get 12 volts <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  through out the  system  but am missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>  at l2660  could you please help me if am wrong let me know thanks

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no fan
threads.message:
Liquid? 12V? Does your multimeter have more digits? <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present? 
Using a good 60W charger?

threads.message:
Are you sure you're measuring <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?
Because if PP3V3 is indeed 15.9V I don't think this board will be fixable due all the damage it has done.

Can you make sure you're measuring <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and not DCIN?

threads.message:
Hm yeah that's indeed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, I doubt this can be fixed as it most likely damaged lots of components.

Just to confirm my suspicion, can you check for continuity on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> <-> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ?

Maybe someone else here has a solution though

threads.message: no continuity  on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> <-> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>   i just check  <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> am not getting 3.4 volts on the right side with resistore  i get 12volts in and 5 volts but not 3.4 v out

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no fan
threads.message: I would clean up obvious corrosion, and remove L7220 to prevent further damage. Check <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> for Drain to Ground Short (Pin 2 - 3), but I am just learning so take it with a grain of salt.

threads.message:
It is impossible to get 15V there if PPBUS is at 12V. Either you are using your multimeter wrong or I don't know what voodoo you are doing.
But if you are sure the measurement is correct then the board is absolutely completely toast.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no fan
threads.message:
I am going to oversimplify. 99% of the time, this will be one of four things.

1) <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground.
2) The IC responsible for creating <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not receiving power on its VIN/VCC/VDD/voltage input pin.
3) The IC responsible for creating <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is bad.
4) The IC responsible for creating <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not being told to create <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.


<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> is an electronic chip, and like all electronic chips, to do something it wants power. What feeds it power? Datasheet says it gets power to do what it does on the VIN pin. VIN, as in, voltage in, as in, power going into it so it can turn on is provided on pin 16. Is pin 16 is getting 12.56v? If not, figure that out. 

Looking at the page, on the side where <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is created, we have a pin called "<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>"... let's guess. P3V3S5 is the name of the rail we are missing. Let's guess what ENTRIP stands for. This means that the chip itself will natrually always create <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, UNLESS you short this pin to ground.

This is the opposite of chips like <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> on this board. With <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>, you send 3v to the enable pin A3 to turn it on. With <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, voltage is already present at its enable pin, internally, inside the chip. <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> is by default off, and must be enabled to turn on. <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is by default on, and must be "disabled" to turn off.

So in order for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> to be turned on, voltage must be allowed to be present at pin 6 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Look at <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>. What does it do? On pins 3 and 4, ,we have a path where <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>[I](which must be present for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> to turn on)[/I] can go straight to ground. What type of transistor is <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>? If we google SSM6N37FEAPE, we see it is an N channel MOSFET, meaning the voltage on the gate must be higher than the voltage on the source for it to turn on.

So, if <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is present, it will send <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> to ground, and we won't get anything on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. Note the _L, and the _EN. This is telling. P3V3S5 is our rail - EN means enable, and _L means while low. So, when that signal is LOW, as in 0v, <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> will not send <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> to ground, and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> will be allowed to turn on. So we need <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> to be low. Where does this come from? 

<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>.. as in, ENable <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. According to your measurements, we have 3.4v there - so the IC responsible for creating <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is being told to turn on. This crosses out #4 as a possible problem.

<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> comes from <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>. <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> takes <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and turns it into <SIGNAL>P5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL> at 3.3v, and then INVERTS it(note the triangle with a dot on it) to 0v for <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>. So, if you are getting <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, which you are, you're at the first step needed for success. Second step will be, is <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> keeping <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> low? If it is, it is doing its job - move on. If not, replace <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>.

If <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is low, move on. Does <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> have voltage present on its entrip pin at pin 6 for <SIGNAL>PP3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>? If yes, then check for short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. If no short to ground, then we have to imagine that <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is dead. Replace <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.

If <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is low, but pin 6 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is also low, then we must explore why this is. Either <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is dead, or <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> is malfunctioning and shorting <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> to ground regardless of whether <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is present or not. 99% of the time this will be bad <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, but removing <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> can be done quickly to help confirm.
